prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Olive Green
Description: An art-school student whose ambition is to become an artist. She's just regained consciousness, having been comatose for days after suffering a stab to from the back.
Character 4
Name: Soseki Natsume
Description: A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime.↳A Japanese scholar sent to London to further his research into the English language. He's just been acquitted of a very serious crime, but now finds himself accused of another.
Character 5
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 6
Name: William Shamspeare
Description: The victim of the current case - a failed actor renting a room in the same building as Mr Natsume's lodgings.
Character 7
Name: John Garrideb
Description: A retired army man who's the landlord of the lodgings rented by the defendant, Mr Natsume. An old knee injury means he's confined to a chair most of the time.
Character 8
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 9
Name: Adron B. Metermann
Description: A young man who works for Altamont Gas. He's a witness to the incident.
Character 10
Name: Quinby Altamont
Description: The wife of the owner of the Altamont Gas Company. She's a staunch believer in the superiority of the fuel and utterly unforgiving of gas theft.
Character 11
Name: Duncan Ross
Description: The love of Miss Green's life, who sadly passed away a month ago as a result of gas poisoning.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Secondhand Book Receipt
Description: A receipt for some books that Mr Natsume purchased at a secondhand bookshop. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 2
Name: Nearby Street Map
Description: A street map of the neighbourhood where Mr Natsume has his lodgings. It was submitted as evidence in the trial the other day.
Evidence 3
Name: Pair of Teacups
Description: The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. The one with the green line around the rim was Mr Natsume's. The teacups used by Mr Shamspeare and Mr Natsume. There is no tea ring on the inside of Mr Natsume's cup.
Evidence 4
Name: Torn-Off End of Envelope
Description: A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. The rest of the envelope could not be located. A ripped piece of an envelope that was found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It fits perfectly with an envelope in Miss Green's possession.
Evidence 5
Name: Bar of Soap
Description: A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. It's one of two that were found there. A cheap bar of soap that was discovered just outside Mr Shamspeare's window. There is a two centimetre diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface.
Evidence 6
Name: Crime Scene Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the scene taken by police upon their arrival. The victim can be seen unconscious at the table, having been poisoned.
Evidence 7
Name: Victim's Medical Report
Description: A report issued by Scotland Yard's medical officer. It obviously mentions the poison as well as other details gleaned during the police investigation.
Evidence 8
Name: Gas Meter
Description: A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. It sports a very strong lock, especially with Mr Shamspeare in mind. A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. The attached coin box sports a very strong lock, and there is a tiny hole in its base.
Evidence 9
Name: Handprints on the Wall
Description: Traces of handprints on the wall, discovered using the Skin Print Seeker gun. There are multiple prints on either side of a hanging picture.
Evidence 10
Name: Capital Offender Article
Description: A newspaper article about Selden, a criminal sentenced to receive the death penalty. However, he died of illness in prison whilst his loot remained undiscovered.
Evidence 11
Name: Hidden Photograph
Description: A photographic print found in Mr Shamspeare's room. It shows the landlord, Mr Garrideb, together with a young man.
Evidence 12
Name: Bottle of Poison
Description: A bottle found in the possession of Miss Green with traces of the slow-acting poison strychnine inside.
Evidence 13
Name: Capital Offender's File
Description: Scotland Yard's file about the convicted criminal Selden that includes the newspaper article about him dying of illness in prison.
Evidence 14
Name: Miss Green's Card
Description: A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. It contains instructions to meet with someone who claims to have information about Duncan Ross. A note in an envelope that seems to have been ripped open rather roughly. The envelope fits perfectly with a torn-off piece found at the scene of the crime.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It was around nine o'clock that evening when I visited my neighbour, and I took some tea with me as a gift.
Person: Soseki
Testimony 1
Testimony: We had a heated literary debate over a nice, hot drink. After which I went back to my room, at around eleven.
Person: Soseki
Testimony 2
Testimony: Argh! My tea was completely harmless! He couldn't have locked the door behind me otherwise, could he?
Person: Soseki
Testimony 3
Testimony: Strychnine takes some time to have an effect on the body. People don't keel over immediately after takin' it.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: The victim would have been perfectly able to lock the door after his guest left. The argument still stands.
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. I'm a bit new to this, so I'll take it step by step.

First, I need to understand the setup. There are several characters involved, including Susato Mikotoba, Iris Wilson, Herlock Sholmes, Olive Green, Soseki Natsume, Tobias Gregson, William Shamspeare, John Garrideb, Barok van Zieks, Adron B. Metermann, and Quinby Altamont. Each has their own description, which might help in understanding their roles.

Looking at the evidences, there are 14 pieces of evidence listed, each with a name and description. The testimonies are from various characters, each giving their account of the incident.

The question is asking which specific evidence and testimony contradict each other. I need to find a pair where one piece of evidence supports one version of events and another testimony contradicts it.

Let me start by looking at the testimonies and see what each one says. 

Testimony 0: Soseki says she visited her neighbor around 9 pm and took tea as a gift.

Testimony 1: Soseki had a heated literary debate with Shamspeare, then went back to her room around 11 pm.

Testimony 2: Soseki claims her tea was harmless, and if the door was locked, she wouldn't have been able to get in afterward.

Testimony 3: Gregson mentions that strychnine takes time to affect someone, so they don't keel over immediately.

Testimony 4: Gregson argues that the victim could have locked the door after Soseki left, supporting the idea that the poison was the cause.

Now, looking at the evidence, let's see what each one says:

Evidence 0: Armband, which is a defense lawyer's identifier.

Evidence 1: Secondhand Book Receipt, submitted as evidence in a trial.

Evidence 2: Nearby Street Map, also submitted in a trial.

Evidence 3: Pair of Teacups, with no tea ring on Natsume's cup.

Evidence 4: Torn-Off Envelope, matching one found at the scene.

Evidence 5: Bar of Soap, with a depression in the middle.

Evidence 6: Crime Scene Photograph, showing the victim poisoned.

Evidence 7: Victim's Medical Report, mentioning poison.

Evidence 8: Gas Meter, locked and with a tiny hole.

Evidence 9: Handprints on the Wall, using a Skin Print Seeker gun.

Evidence 10: Capital Offender Article, about a criminal who died in prison.

Evidence 11: Hidden Photograph, showing Garrideb and a young man.

Evidence 12: Bottle of Poison, found in Green's possession with strychnine.

Evidence 13: Capital Offender's File, about Selden's death.

Evidence 14: Miss Green's Card, a note ripped roughly, matching a torn piece at the scene.

Now, focusing on the testimonies related to the poison and the time of effect:

Testimony 3 and 4 both mention strychnine and the time it takes to affect someone. Gregson says it takes time, so people don't keel over immediately (Testimony 3). He also argues that the victim could have locked the door after Soseki left, supporting that the poison was the cause (Testimony 4).

Looking at the evidence, Evidence 12 is the Bottle of Poison found in Green's possession with strychnine. If this is the poison used, it supports the idea that the victim was poisoned, aligning with Testimony 4.

But Testimony 3 says strychnine takes time, so the victim wouldn't keel over immediately. However, Evidence 7 is the Victim's Medical Report, which also mentions poison. If the Medical Report confirms the cause of death as poison, that aligns with Testimony 4.

Wait, but if Evidence 12 is the poison bottle found in Green's possession, and the Medical Report (Evidence 7) confirms poison as the cause, then both support the idea that the victim died from poison, which aligns with Gregson's statements.

But the contradiction might be elsewhere. Let me think again.

Testimony 2: Soseki claims her tea was harmless. If her tea was harmless, then she didn't poison the victim, supporting that the victim was poisoned by someone else, possibly Green.

But Evidence 12 is the poison bottle found in Green's possession, suggesting Green is the one who poisoned the victim. So Testimony 2 (Soseki's statement) contradicts Evidence 12 if Soseki is innocent.

Wait, but Testimony 2 is Soseki's own testimony, so if her tea was harmless, that supports her innocence, but the evidence points to Green as the poisoner. So the contradiction would be that Soseki claims her tea was harmless, implying she didn't do it, but the evidence shows Green did.

But the question is to find which evidence and testimony directly contradict each other. So perhaps it's between Testimony 2 and Evidence 12.

Alternatively, maybe between Testimony 3 and Evidence 7.

Wait, Testimony 3: Gregson says strychnine takes time, so the victim wouldn't have died immediately. Evidence 7: Medical Report mentions poison, which aligns with Gregson's statement. So they support each other, not contradict.

Wait, maybe Testimony 2 and Evidence 12. Soseki says her tea was harmless, but Evidence 12 shows Green had poison, implying Green is the killer. So Soseki's testimony supports her innocence, while the evidence points to Green, creating a contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 and Evidence 8. Testimony 4 says the victim could have locked the door after Soseki left, supporting that the poison was the cause. Evidence 8 is the Gas Meter, which is locked, supporting that the door was locked after Soseki left, making it impossible for her to enter afterward. So both support the same idea, not contradicting.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 12. If Soseki's tea was harmless, then she didn't poison the victim, but Evidence 12 shows Green did. So Soseki's testimony supports her innocence, but the evidence shows Green is guilty, which is a contradiction.

But the question is to find one pair. So perhaps Testimony 2 and Evidence 12.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 3 and Evidence 7. Gregson says strychnine takes time, and the Medical Report confirms poison. So they support each other.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 12. Soseki says her tea was harmless, but Green had poison, implying she's the killer. So Soseki's testimony and the evidence contradict each other.

Yes, that seems to be the case. Soseki is claiming her tea was harmless, but the evidence shows Green had the poison, making Soseki's testimony incorrect if Green is the killer.

So the pair would be Testimony 2 and Evidence 12.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I'm proud to be the company's East End branch investigator and meter money collection agent.
Person: Metermann
Testimony 1
Testimony: Altamont gas meters accept thruppenny bits, each coin givin' customers about two hours of gorgeous gas!
Person: Metermann
Testimony 2
Testimony: And yet, the meter in Mr Shamspeare's room didn't have a single coin in it!
Person: Altamont
Testimony 3
Testimony: The meter doesn't appear to have been tampered with, though, and the collection agent has the only key.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 4
Testimony: All joints on the meter are welded shut, and the lock is made from solid steel. There's no way to dismantle it.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 5
Testimony: The meter is designed for coins the exact diameter and thickness of a thruppenny bit. Nothing else will fit.
Person: Altamont
Testimony 6
Testimony: Somehow, he's usin' all the flamin' gas he wants without payin' a penny! If that's not thievin', what is?!
Person: Metermann

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. So, I have a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. The goal is to find one pair where the evidence directly contradicts the testimony. 

First, I'll need to go through each piece of evidence and each testimony to see where there's a conflict. Let's start by understanding the key points from each.

Looking at the testimonies, Testimony 2 from Person: Altamont says, "And yet, the meter in Mr Shamspeare's room didn't have a single coin in it!" That seems important because it suggests that the gas meter wasn't paying for gas, which could imply that the gas was stolen or used without payment. 

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 8 is the Gas Meter. It says, "A meter that dispenses gas for a set time after a coin is inserted. The attached coin box sports a very strong lock, and there is a tiny hole in its base." This suggests that the meter requires a coin to dispense gas, and the coin box is securely locked. 

So, Testimony 2 states that the meter didn't have any coins, which would mean no gas was dispensed. But Evidence 8 indicates that the meter is designed to only dispense gas when a coin is inserted. If there were no coins, the meter wouldn't dispense gas, which aligns with Testimony 2. 

Wait, that doesn't seem contradictory. Maybe I'm missing something. Let's think again. Testimony 2 is from Quinby Altamont, who is the wife of the owner of Altamont Gas. She's upset because the meter wasn't collecting coins, implying that someone is stealing gas. Evidence 8 explains that the meter requires a coin to dispense gas, and it's locked. 

So, if the meter didn't have any coins, that supports the idea of theft because the gas was being used without paying. But is there a contradiction here? Not directly. Maybe I should look elsewhere.

Let me check other testimonies. Testimony 5 from Metermann says, "The meter is designed for coins the exact diameter and thickness of a thruppenny bit. Nothing else will fit." That's about the meter's design. 

Looking at Evidence 5, which is the Bar of Soap, it says, "There is a two centimetre diameter circular depression in the middle of one surface." That doesn't seem related to the gas meter. 

Wait, maybe I should look at the testimonies again. Testimony 4 from Altamont says, "All joints on the meter are welded shut, and the lock is made from solid steel. There's no way to dismantle it." That reinforces the idea that the meter is secure and can't be tampered with. 

But Testimony 6 from Metermann says, "Somehow, he's usin' all the flamin' gas he wants without payin' a penny! If that's not thievin', what is?!" This suggests that someone is using gas without paying, which would mean the meter wasn't collecting coins. 

So, putting it all together: 

- Testimony 2 and Testimony 6 both state that the meter didn't have any coins.
- Evidence 8 explains that the meter requires a coin to dispense gas.
- Testimony 4 mentions that the meter is secure and can't be dismantled.
- Testimony 5 explains the meter's design, which matches Evidence 8.

I think the contradiction might be between Testimony 6 and Evidence 8. Testimony 6 suggests that gas was being used without paying, implying the meter wasn't working or was tampered with. But Evidence 8 says the meter is secure and requires a coin. If the meter was working and needed a coin, then Testimony 6's claim of using gas without paying would be impossible. Therefore, Testimony 6 contradicts Evidence 8 because the meter's design and security features make it impossible to use gas without paying.

So, the pair that contradicts each other is Evidence 8 and Testimony 6.
</think>
